p:
The spatial ecology of invasive species has received considerable attention in the past decade
1– 6 . Spatial ecology offers unique insights into how organisms organize and utilize habitats across both space and time. Geostatistical and spatial analyses identify predictable invasion patterns of invasive pests, which aid in describing how these species colonize foreign habitats and what landscape attributes contribute to the their success
7, 8 . Importantly, the use of spatial ecology in pest management can identify vulnerable ecosystems (agricultural and otherwise) as well as inherent weaknesses in the pest’s ecology which may be exploited in management efforts.
